title: Multilingual Linked Open Data Patterns

author: José Emilio Labra Gayo, University of Oviedo at Gijón

segmentation: Good morning, I was Amelia library come from the University of Oviedo but this work has been made with Dimitrius Contra Costa's from Greece and sorry nowhere from Lexie.
And last workshop I presented also a paper related with this.
It was called the best practices on multilingual linked open data.

But after giving the talk, I was thinking that maybe some of those best practices were not so much best practices, but maybe they work patterns and sometimes you have to select if you take one of those patterns and you take another pattern pattern can be more like a generic solution to a problem.
And I think it is good to have a catalog of patterns that you can select.
You can so you can have a common vocabulary is to say well I am using full IRS or I'm using descriptive URLs.
These kind of things that I think could help when we are discussing with this the best solution to develop multilingual link data application.
And so I have done a catalog of patterns.
Each pattern has a name or description or context.
I tried to give some motivating examples, discussion and some relationships with other patterns.
Also, I have prepared a small web page that you have the link down in the slides and it contains all the patterns on the table so you can see it with more.
More detail this paper has I also prepared a paper with this.
We all relate the catalog of patterns with the experience of the Pedia International.
So that's what has down limited control costs.
So.
The patterns the catalog of patterns were divided were classified in the different things we have to do when we are preparing linked data solutions, we have to name to have a UI scheme.
We also have to do the reference to say which content we provide.
We also have to label.
We also have long descriptions.
We also have linkings between the different concepts and we have to take into account registry stability.
So this is the catalog of patterns.
This is a 20 patterns.
Of course I could have more patterns and so that's the reason of this talk.
Is that maybe it would be interesting from the community to have more patterns and to add to have more discussing about this and the rest of the talk.
I'm going to present the patterns an when they when I have more times I will cut so it's just to go.
It's pattern one by one.
So what I will do is to present a very small example that I think we useful to know about all the patterns emerging that you want to describe.
Just this sentence that you have a person that is called Jan. One is an Armenian Chris professor at the University of Long, so this should we semantic web, we have this person.
This is the country where he was born.
And then the position and the University of Lyon.
Notice that are many eyes, country that they speak in a different language.
And if we different characters and they also has an accent.
So the first thing is to name into name what?
Patterns, so we used to have a UI or what are the different possibilities where the first possibility is to have what I?
This pattern is very easy as descriptive julies.
So for example in the case of Armenia we could say, well this is example DOT or RG and this is Lars Armenia.
This is very easy.
This is human readable.
We have very good tool support for descriptive URLs, but there is a limitation that they're only ASCII.
ASCII characters and only ASCII characters.
For example, in the case of University, does delay on the link would be that one that is in red, and that's more difficult to handle.
So and also that there are human readability crisis so.
There is another pattern that I that is also used in other contexts.
It's opaque, your eyes is going to have local names that are not human readable at all, so you say, well, this is like just this identifier Ann.
This is also useful because in some context you want to have an in depth independent I idea of the concept and that's independent from the natural language representation.
So you have the only provide.
Identifier that is unique and then you have to provide different levels, so this is good.
But also this is also difficult to handle by developers and also if you have linked data application, this is very difficult to handle.
The different UI is because they are opaque identifiers.
I know this solution could be full, I arise in this case of Armenia.
It could be something like this.
They are nice and they are human readable in the case for people who speaks Armenian, I don't know how many of you speak Armenian, but you know maybe for us is there are more difficult.
But for Armenian people they're much more human readable and.
But there is a problem with full high rises.
The also have the problem of security.
You know there are.
There are some glyphs in Unicode characters that they look the same, but they are different characters so that it can be exposed to some security issues.
So there is another.

Pattern that is, some is more used is to have what I called internationalized local names is that you have the domain name is only in ASCII and ASCII characters, but the local name can be internationalized.
For example you can have Unicode characters.
This pattern, for example is the one that they are using.
DV Pedia international international.
They have the local parts is dbpedia.org, but then the domain.
Sorry the domain name is.
Pedia dot already.
But the local part is in Unicode characters.
The advantage of this pattern is that the security is improved because the domain name is preserved by the ASCII characters.
And also let her another pattern.
I didn't present this last day in the last workshop.
Is that when you include the language stack in the UI, for example in the PDR they use this pattern to separate the independent development of the different data sets.
For example, the Pedia English well, this is also by default we indentified by North, but depending arghamanyan could be identified by Hy.
But this is important to notice the difference between languages and countries.
Hi comes from higher end that is not Armenia would be AM.
But there's other patterns.
For example, indicates of the reference other potencies.
What?
What data should we provide?
We can provide for example, the same content of the same data independent of language, content devastation.

But there is another pattern that may be useful, but this is not very used at all, but it is that when you use language content negotiation so if someone goes to this UI of Armenia and he says that he accepts the language English, we return English.
Tribles, but if he says.
He accepts the language, higher rank of Armenian with return triples in Armenian.

This is a interesting thing because the you will have the low bandwidth and network overhead is lower, but you also have to take into account if the semantic equivalence of the data that you submit is the same.
So this can raise other issues.
In the case of leveling, this is another pattern that is labeled everything.
This pattern can also comes from the book was leaking linked data patterns, so this is the same pattern is to provide levels like.
I think it is good in general also for user Agent San.
And also we can have another very common pattern is to have multilingual labels.
So if we are in a multilingual application we have different labels for the different languages.
This is good, but there is a small issue.
We only have multilingual labels, it is when for example this sparkle query that it is very simple.
We are only asking if there is someone who is a professor and we have data set.
Notice that this simple sparkle query would return nothing because all the literals have language tag, so this is a small issue, so there is another.

After that, another suggestion is to have also label label with no language stack, so this is in some applications could be used so it could be useful, but of course there's also the problem that which language should we have as a default?
So this is not so.
Maybe this is.
Also this could be an anti pattern or a pattern depends.
Well, another thing that take into account is what about longer descriptions?
Longer descriptions, for example, could we run the job title?
Is Professor of the University of Learn the problem with longer descriptions is that they are very difficult to handle.
Also in linked data, so maybe probably in general it is better to have more fine grained descriptions and to say, well we have one position.
Is professor at the University workplaces uni leonin?
Be more separated.
I think this is in general better, but of course it is not always feasible.

Then there is another pattern is when in some applications maybe we need more detail of the descriptions, so for example to describe University of Lyon, we want to say we have a University we have off and we have long and we have we have long is an unknown and University is a another thing.
So we have more detail in the descriptions.
I'm.
Finally, maybe people are not so aware that also in linked data within RDF we also have the possibility to include a structure literal, so if it is, we have XML literals and we can have them.
Maybe they are good and we are with this kind of literals.
We can liberate all the internationalization guidelines for XML and HTML, so we can just include that.
But there is the problem of the different levels of abstraction between semantic web, RDF, XML and HTML, so that's something that we have to take it back out.
In the case of linking, there is other patterns, for example to have the same concepts that are in different languages and to say we can say that they are the same.
This approach was taken in the pedia, but this is dangerous because sometimes the datasets come from different sources and sometimes you can have contradictions.
So there is another pattern could be so.
Links that you have, for example, you say, well, this is this concept.
You can see also another concept in another in another language or for example in the pedia.
They have this wiki page language link to say that those two concepts are related by Inter language links.
Finally, we also have the possibility to have linked to links to linguistic data.
For example, we can say categorical is a down.
In Spanish, the word expense.
So this is like we can have first class language annotations that sometimes in some applications could be useful.
Well, we also have a book.
I have some patterns for use in the case of reused.
What I think here this is this pattern is called monolingual vocabularies.
We can have vocabularies in English, so this is the for example.
Most of the most common vocabularies in semantic web or only in English.
They are monolingual at all.
This is maybe sometimes it's better, but also he has some difficulties.
So there is another possibility to have multilingual vocabularies.
Multilingual vocabularies is when you have the different concepts they are translated but also the maintenance is more difficult.
And just to finish also, we also have.
This is probably the last ones we have.
Also another part is localized, 16 vocabularies is when you have for example some properties from Dublin Core and you want to have them translated to Spain and you just translate that.
So that's that.
You localize the system vocabularies.
Another possibility is to create new localized vocabularies.
For example, you say well, instead of translating directly that you just say that, well, you have another property property that could be colaborador and you relate those properties.
So this is the end and the end.
This is not the end.
I mean this is the end of this talk, but we have another session and today and at lunchtime that is devoted to best practices in multilingual linked data in general.
So I think the now the opportunity is your opportunityto improve this catalog.
This is just a first approximation of catalog and I think it would be interesting if you participate.
You contribute with other patterns or best practices and also some.
The Potters problems.
Maybe some of these patterns could be considered good, or maybe bad practices, so this is also their assigned users that I didn't take into account.
For example, the macro data or DFA.
These kind of things should also have some patterns to take into account, so I think that's.
Thank you very much.
You are perfect.
